results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron [Spectrum 48/128 emulation]
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021
results.description:

Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Mary's Story
results.creator_credit: Mary Herbert and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Mary tells of her personal experience living with cerebral palsy. She recounts being told she could never walk, but her parents, determined that she could, helped her achieve this milestone. Mary goes on to speak about the troubles she has faced later in life.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Quilts of Understanding
results.creator_credit: Jenene Egan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
In this story, Jenene tells of her life-long passion for all things craft. Recounting one of her proudest moments, she speaks about some patches that she created for a collaborative quilt-making project, which was exhibited at her Uniting Church and throughout regional Victoria.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Generations of Hands
results.creator_credit: Jennette Moore and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Jennette was born in Ballarat. In this digital story, she talks about her personal experience growing up as a deaf person. She recalls learning how to sign and memories with her little brother and parents. Jennette also tells of her children (one of whom was sadly still-born) and grandchildren.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: The Next Chapter
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Craig Dawson
results.brief_description:
Craig Dawson shares his personal experience of being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, a disease that his grandmother also suffered from. Craig dedicates this story to her.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: How to Sell to Australia
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

constellations_primary.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_primary.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million views on YouTube with the campaign’s song known globally, having charted on iTunes in 28 countries. While light-hearted, at its core the hugely successful commercial carries a serious message: Be Safe Around Trains.

results.description: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.
description_for_label: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-07. Birth of Television → MI-07-AV01

results.title: Ohnar 16MM Editor Viewer
results.brief_description: Film viewing and editing devices like the Ohnar provided amatuer filmmakers the ability to precisely edit their own home movies with relative ease. Popular among avid consumer-level filmmakers for their size, this 16mm film equipment allows hand cranking and has a convenient frame counting dial. The reel arms can be swivelled out and locked in place for use, and folded away for compact storage.
results.description: Film viewing and editing devices like the Ohnar provided amatuer filmmakers the ability to precisely edit their own home movies with relative ease. Popular among avid consumer-level filmmakers for their size, this 16mm film equipment allows hand cranking and has a convenient frame counting dial. The reel arms can be swivelled out and locked in place for use, and folded away for compact storage.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Foyer → Entry → FSF-03. MPL exterior

group_siblings.title: 16mm projector
group_siblings.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).

results.title: 16mm Film
results.brief_description: Most of the films in our collection are held on 16mm film, which was introduced in the 1920s as a cheaper alternative to the 35mm format and was widely adopted by amateur filmmakers. Because of its accessibility and popularity, it’s no surprise that we receive so many donations from the community, which along with the film itself, also comprises editing equipment and cameras. The Hanimex Eiki 16mm film projector displayed in this cabinet is typical of the kinds used in schools up until the 1980s, where films were screened in assembly halls to supplement standard learning in classrooms.
results.description: Most of the films in our collection are held on 16mm film, which was introduced in the 1920s as a cheaper alternative to the 35mm format and was widely adopted by amateur filmmakers. Because of its accessibility and popularity, it’s no surprise that we receive so many donations from the community, which along with the film itself, also comprises editing equipment and cameras. The Hanimex Eiki 16mm film projector displayed in this cabinet is typical of the kinds used in schools up until the 1980s, where films were screened in assembly halls to supplement standard learning in classrooms.
description_for_label: Most of the films in our collection are held on 16mm film, which was introduced in the 1920s as a cheaper alternative to the 35mm format and was widely adopted by amateur filmmakers. Because of its accessibility and popularity, it’s no surprise that we receive so many donations from the community, which along with the film itself, also comprises editing equipment and cameras. The Hanimex Eiki 16mm film projector displayed in this cabinet is typical of the kinds used in schools up until the 1980s, where films were screened in assembly halls to supplement standard learning in classrooms.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image →  Foyer → Entry  → 03. MPL exterior

group_works.title: 16mm projector
group_works.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).

results.title: Cigarettes
results.material_description:
Digital video, bespoke artist box
edition 4 of 6 (+2 artist's proofs)
single channel 4:3 animation, colour, silent, continuous loop
media player, two SD cards, archival USB drive
results.brief_description:
“Cigarettes” is a single-channel projected animation, created as part of the “Christian Marclay: Six Animations” exhibition, which debuted at 49 Geary Street, San Francisco, April 28 – June 25 2016. In this animation, static photographs of cigarette butts have been edited together and played back in quick succession to give the illusion of motion.

Unlike traditional animation in which the setting is consistent and spatial continuity is maintained, in this work the background changes frantically. The flickering images recall flip-books, early cinema, and animation devices of the late nineteenth century, such as the zoetrope used by Eadweard Muybridge. Marclay’s animations set the discarded trails of rubbish in motion, giving the humble objects new life and transforming his chance encounters with trash into visual poetry.

Sourced from Fraenkel Gallery: https://fraenkelgallery.com/exhibitions/christian-marclay-six-new-animations
